bibl.title: Henry Imhof v. LV Wykcoff. Complaint
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.ab: In the District Court holding terms at Seattle in the County of King
In the matter of the Application of Henry Imhof for a writ of Habeas Corpus
To the Honorable Roger S Greene. Judge of said Court
div1.p: That he is unlawfully restrained of his liberty of L.V. Wyckoff at Seattle, in the County of King, in the Territory of Washington

That the cause of said restraint is a commitment issued by James P. Ludlow, Esquire, United States Commissioner for the Third Judicial District in said Territory, in which the complaintant is charged with manufactoring, selling, giving, and disposing of beer at Ditka, in the Territory of Alaska and a commitment issued by said James P. Ludlow in which complaintaint is charged with selling giving and disposing of beer
to certain Indians at Ditka in the Territory of Alaska.

That the said restraint is illegal and the illegality thereof consists in this, that neither of the charges against this complaintinant consitutes a criminal offence under the laws of the United States or of this territory.

Wherefore the complaintant prays that a writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted directed to said LV Wyckoff commanding him to have the body of the complainant and said writ before your Honor at a time and place to be therein specified, and that he make known to your Honor the cause of the detention of the complainant; and that the complainant may be restored to liberty.
div1.ab: Territory of Washington County of King SS
div1.p:
Henry Imhof being duly sworn says that he is the above named complainant; that he has heard the foregoing complaint read
knows the contents thereof and believes the same to be true.
div1.ab: Subscribed and sworn to before me this 5th day of November A.D. 1881
James P Ludlow Deputy Clerk Herein
No 2771 In the District COurt King County In the Matter of the application of Henry Imhof for a writ of habeas corpus
Complaint Filed November 5th 1881 James Seavey, Clerk. By James P Ludlow Deputy Clerk. McNaught + McCT Atty for Complaint
